entry.title: Introducing the New Pricing and Packaging for SAP Build: A Unified Experience for all Developers
entry.content:
As SAP is evolving its Business Suite, AI, and Data Products to meet rising market demands, and as part of this strategy, we are introducing a new exciting, unified commercial model for SAP Build. This updated offering consolidates capabilities for pro-code, low code and AI powered development tools making it easier than ever to build applications and extensions within the SAP ecosystem.

With built-in access to runtime, automation, and extensibility services, SAP Build now empowers both business users and professional developers to choose the right tool set for the right job. The integration of generative AI enhances productivity by streamlining workflows, automating tasks, and accelerating decision-making.

To further support development, SAP Build capabilities along with SAP HANA Cloud are now fully included in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Packages empowering customers to handle the majority of their expected scenarios right out of the box. Read the full announcement here.

What changes?

We've heard our customers loud and clear; they asked for simpler licensing, easier provisioning, and a unified toolset. Previously, each SAP Build product like Build Apps, Process Automation, Work Zone, Build Code, and ABAP was licensed separately. This resulted in having lots of different services for customers to manage.  

The following list of 14 services from SAP Build have now been consolidated:

SAP Build Services:

  • SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition
  • SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition
  • SAP Build Process Automation
  • SAP Task Center
  • SAP Build Apps
  • SAP Mobile Services
  • Application Frontend Service
  • SAP Business Application Studio

 SAP Build Runtime Services:

  • SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry Runtime
  • SAP BTP ABAP environment
  • SAP BTP, Kyma runtime
  • SAP Document Management Service
  • SAP Cloud Transport Management
  • SAP Continuous Integration and Delivery

 Now you can access the full range of SAP Build capabilities listed above through just four distinct licenses:

SAP Build base user

This edition is for users who need to access applications, gain insights for day-to-day business needs, and approve tasks. SAP Build base user includes:

  • Access to digital workspaces
  • Access web and mobile apps
  • Request and approve workflow tasks
  • Access mobile start
  • 1000 API Calls
  • 100 MB Storage

 Note: Prerequisite is at least one Build Developer license to manage SAP Build.

 SAP Build premium user

This edition is for users who author content, monitor processes, customize pages, and deploy bots. SAP Build premium user includes:

  • Everything in SAP Build base user, plus
  • Monitor processes via the dashboard
  • Deploy attended robotic process automation bots
  • Author and access workspace content
  • Visually design digital workspaces and guided experiences
  • 1000 API Calls
  • 100 MB Storage

 Note: Prerequisite is at least one Build Developer license to manage SAP Build.

SAP Build developer

This edition is for users who develop application/extensions, workflows, and automations for S/4 and other LoB apps. SAP Build developer includes:

  • Everything in SAP Build premium user, plus
  • Build with low-code/no-code developer tools
  • Develop with code-first developer tools (IDEs)
  • Create and deploy apps and extensions
  • Develop and deploy mobile applications
  • Design and deploy workflows
  • 5000 API Calls
  • 500 MB Storage

SAP Build runtime

Required for application-hosting and lifecycle management services that support the creation and execution for dev/test as well as production environments. SAP Build runtime includes:

  • SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry runtime
  • SAP BTP ABAP Environment
  • SAP BTP, Kyma runtime
  • Application runtime
  • Document management storage and API
  • Cloud transport management
  • Continuous integration and continuous delivery (CI/CD)

Note: Customers can access applications hosted on runtimes without using any end-user capabilities. This ensures customers aren't charged for user licenses they don’t actively use.

Find detailed information about SAP Build and what’s in scope on the SAP Help Portal. 

What are the key benefits of the new SAP Build packaging, and how will it help our customers?

The new SAP Build packaging delivers a streamlined, powerful experience for building extensions, automations, and apps across the SAP ecosystem. Here's how it benefits customers:

  • Unified Access Across Tools: SAP Build now brings together low-code, pro-code, and AI-powered development tools under a single license removing the complexity of managing multiple products and licenses.
  • Built-In ERP Integration: SAP Build and SAP HANA Cloud entitlements are now included in SAP Cloud ERP Private Packages, enabling faster innovation and development for SAP S/4HANA Cloud customers.
  • Empowerment for Developers & Business Users: Both professional developers and key users gain the flexibility to personalize SAP systems with greater speed up to 3x faster, according to
  • Optimized Cost & Efficiency: A flexible, usage-based runtime model helps reduce total cost of ownership and streamline operational overhead.
  • Simplified Governance: A unified licensing approach improves compliance management and centralizes governance across all tools.
  • Business Value First: By removing commercial and technical barriers, organizations can focus more on driving transformation and delivering real business outcomes.

With SAP Build, customers can:

  • Scale confidently within the SAP ecosystem: Use included licenses to rapidly build compliant extensions that align with SAP standards and scale across the enterprise.
  • Leverage AI to boost productivity: Automate complex cross-system processes with AI agents, customize Joule with skill-specific tasks, and speed up development using SAP-optimized AI tools.
  • Deliver faster from front-end to full-stack: Build complete extensions with prebuilt templates, low-code tools, and integrated services like authentication, deployment, and lifecycle management—all on a single, seamless platform.

 Commercial Model and Availability

As of 22nd April 2025, SAP Build is available to customers for subscription only. Availability for consumption under BTPEA and PayGo is anticipated by the end of Q2.

Call to action

  • Visit the SAP Build pricing page to learn more
  • Help portal documentation
  • Register for the SAP Build webinar on May 8th
  • Read the full announcement here
  • Visit the SAP Discovery Center for more details.
  • Review pricing on Discovery Center

entry.title: Partners unlock innovation with latest SAP Build capabilities
entry.content:
20 Partners from 10 countries participated and built innovative solutions during the recently concluded Hack2Build on SAP Build. With the latest SAP Build capabilities delivered recently by SAP, Partners explored and leveraged key functionalities of the low-code, pro-code and generative AI tools for building their innovations.

Partners extend, create, and automate with SAP Build

In this Hack2Build edition, partner used SAP Build Apps, SAP Build Work Zone, and SAP Build Process Automation integration and built applications to guide users through a multi-step process and efficient completion of complex business processes. Partners also used SAP Build Code, the AI-powered code assistance for application creation and code optimization.

The hack phase started on April 8,2025, and concluded on April 15, 2025, with two demo jams. The demo jam saw the partners present their innovations developed using SAP Build in just five working days. A panel of judges chose three winners each, impressed by high-powered pitches.

Hack2Build SAP Build-Partners who participated in the final demo jamIn this blog, we will highlight the three winners from each of the two groups who showcased their innovations developed on SAP Build.

Group 1 Winners

Hack2Build SAP Build - Group1 winners

 Jupiter 2000 showcased a Building Facade Inspection Safety Program (FISP) Application enhancing building inspections with AI-generated suggestions and with guided experience report submission. The guided experience offers inspectors to fill out reports accurately and in compliance with regulations. Using SAP AI Core, AI-Powered photo identification for crack detection and image recognition to generate automatically description of facade defects with manual override as needed. The application allows for reviewing, editing, and submitting inspection reports before final approval with a possibility of submission to government departments for streamlined reporting.

Jupiter 2000's Façade Inspection Safety Program (FISP) Application

Reply introduced NextGen Service Portal designed to improve service request reporting by providing a guided, web-based experience for reporting service tickets using SAP Work Zone and SAP Build Apps. It is a pre-configured guided solution for service-intensive industries which allows internal employees, external partners, and even unknown users to report issues through a simple visual and structured web-based experience. With a guided step-by-step process to report service tickets, structured data input, capability of interactive floor maps and upload of photos, the data can flow directly to SAP Service Cloud for real-time ticket management.

NextGen Service Portal by Reply

EY developed Smart Automation of Goods Receipts and Purchase Order creation with a central SAP Work Zone site and SAP Build Apps for purchase order (PO) creation, and goods receipt QR Code scanning which eliminates the need for third-party scanner tools, utilizing AI for planning suggestions. The solution eliminates the need for third-party scanner tools, offers a Clean Core compliant and AI-integrated process, with automated and Instant creation of Goods Receipts (GR) or Goods Issues (GI) in SAP S/4HANA, enhancing efficiency and flexibility for warehouse staff using mobile devices.

EY's Smart Automation of Goods Receipts and Purchase Order creation

Group 2 Winners

Hack2Build SAP Build - Group2 winners

MOURI Tech developed Guide2Resolve, a complaint resolution solution to streamline complaints at large events like expos and provide enhanced attendee experience and improved organizational efficiency. Guide2Resolve simplifies and accelerates the complaint submission and resolution process using a guided Process, structured, and automated flow powered by SAP Build Work Zone and UI Integration Cards. Generative AI determines category based on issue description.

Guide2Resolve application by MOURI Tech

Cognizant showcased their Case management AI Agent for SAP. They offer a side by side extensibility solution that adheres to SAP clean core principles designed to automate processes, provides user guidance, and improves efficiency, particularly notable in the utilities sector. The solution brings a unified view of all exceptions, and offers case resolution using guided procedures, utilizes SAP Build, Work Zone, and Process Automation to create an efficient digital workspace. The solution harnesses the power of generative AI to deliver a suite of multi-agents that transform case management.

Case Management AI Agent for SAP by Cognizant

NTT Data’s agri business solution seeks to improve the integration of large-scale weighing operations, crucial for grain transportation. The application receive weights and quality analysis upon soft commodity movements, indicate which trading contract should be used, allows automatic or manual application to contracts, executes goods movement and issues invoicing documents. The solution developed with SAP Build Work Zone with the support of Joule during the development process, utilizes SAP CAP with SAP HANA HDI Containers with a custom SAPUI5 front end. The solution connects to SAP S/4HANA applications by the SAP Cloud Connector.

 NTT Agro – Scale and application

Judges 

Many thanks to the panel of judges who spent considerable time to evaluate and share feedback on the innovative solutions presented by the partners.

Pavel PenazGlobal Vice President & Head of Partner Solution Success BTP & AI, SAP Czech Republic
Kathrin HettelVice President, Strategic Cross-Portfolio & AI Partnership, SAP SE
Julia IvanovaSAP Build Product Management, SAP SE
Marc HuberSAP Build Product Management, SAP SE
Sruthi ChiramelSAP Build Product Management, SAP SE
Stephan KoenigSAP Build Product Management, SAP SE
Neeraj UpretiSAP Ecosystem Development Manager, SAP America

Special Thanks

We extend our appreciation to the SAP team members from SAP Build Product Management and Partner Solution Success, who coached the partners to successfully develop their solutions during the Hack2Build SAP Build initiative.

Next Phase

Partners have expressed their interest to complete their full scope solution in 10 weeks. Partner Solution Success will engage with all the participating partners to support their build journey in the next weeks and get their innovations ready for customer adoption.

entry.title: Add Value Help with SAP Build Actions (free project)
entry.content:
Value help is one of the key features that can make a UI really friendly. Here's how to do it without much work, using the new integration of Actions with SAP Build Apps.

Even if you do not need value help, you can learn from this project:

  • Actions (including custom $filter)
  • 🆕 New page variables based on existing schema feature
  • Custom events
  • Popups (including showing/hiding and absolute positioning)
  • Layouting and positioning 
  • Events related to input box
  • 🆕 Integrating actions into SAP Build Apps 
  • Working with destinations to retrieve S/4HANA data
  • Paging and filtering

As always we will use the A_BusinessPartner entity so the user can easily select a business partner. The app has 2 ways to provide the value help:

🟪From within an Input Box:

🟪From another screen that lists all the business partners, using paging and filtering:

NOTE: This technique is good for an OData v2 service. You can do the same for a v4 service, though there you could use the CONTAINS keyword in the action or even skip the action and use a "Get record collection" to do the filtering work, since for v4 services this flow function provides the contains filtering option.

Much of the idea for this UI is based on a blog by @botazhat and her blog How to add a search bar with suggestions in SAP Build Apps. I have enhanced it by using actions, and making it work with v2 services and taking data directly from SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

 

Create Action for Getting Help Values

I think it is better design to use an action to get the help values since it.

  • Hides the API calls from the app developer
  • Hides the filtering syntax, which can be complex and different between OData v2 and v4
  • Makes the front-end development simpler

You can download the project, though it is quite simple to create yourself.

All you have to do to get started is create an action based on the BusinessPartner API service, and use the simple GET all business partners call from the A_BusinessPartner entity.

You will make a few small changes to make it easier to work with:

  • Add filterString as an input parameter to get a string to search in the business partner name.
  • Set defaults for some of the OData query parameters:
    • Set $top to 20, to retrieve only 20 matches at once (this can be overridden by the app)
    • Set $orderby to sort by BusinessPartnerFullName is ascending order (but you can change this)
    • Set $inlinecount to allpages, to return the total number of records, for the case where we paginate through the values.

For the filtering, we set the $filter input. Click the row, which opens the side panel. Then in the side panel, click to open the expression editor.

This will let you you set the $filter clause, either with a GUI or manually by typing in whatever you want.

This is the expression I used, to search for all matches on the BusinessPartnerFullName field using the value in filterString, and eliminating all business partners with no name. Note in v4 we would have had simpler syntax with the CONTAINS keyword.

substringof('${filterString}',BusinessPartnerFullName) eq true and BusinessPartnerFullName ne ''

Release and publish the action.

 

The Project

You can download the project we used to see how the UI, variables and logic. To use it, you'll have to connect your own deployed action. I've tried to make it as generic as possible.

There 2 pages, each providing a different way to get value help:

  • Home Page: Contains the form for business partner ID and name, plus the dropdown to search for a specific business partner.
  • Business Partners: Contains a list of all business partners that you can paginate through or search through.

And we have 2 app variables to store the business partner ID and name.

UI for Dropdown Help

For both pages, we create an integration to the action, and to the destination to be used with the action. Notice that here we create an integration to a destination without enabling any entities -- this was a little weird to me the first time I saw it. 

For variables, we have these:

  • Action_In and Action_Out are created automatically with the new feature that allows you to create variables from an action's schema.
  • filterString is the search string.
  • events is a way to control the updates when someone types fast and reduce the number of calls to the backend (write a comment if you want to learn more). 

And the logic is pretty simple with only 3 main flow functions (skipping all the flow functions related to the events variable):

  1. We capture when someone types in the search field (EVENT)
  2. We ignore when the search string is less than 3 characters (IF CONDITION)
  3. We then run the action (TRIGGER ACTION)
  4. We set the variable to hold the returned values (SET PAGE VARIABLE)

We also added some simple logic to handle when the user leaves the search box or presses escape (clear the value help) or when the user returns (run the original logic above with custom event). 

As for the UI, the main thing is the container holding the value help is absolutely positioned so it aligns with the input box:

And its visibility is set only when there are options to display:

UI for Selecting from All Values

Instead of using a dropdown, we added an icon at the end of the input box that navigates to a different page for selecting the business partner. 

This takes us to a separate page where we display all the business partners, and we can use filtering or paging to find the record we want.

This is the only logic we have, on the page logic canvas (except for clicking one of the business partners and returning to the home page).

When we come to the page we load all the business partners, and we have a custom event to refresh the page whenever we need to.

Then we have 3 flows when different page variables change:

  • User changes search string: We reset the page number to 1 and the OData $skip parameter to 0, and call the backend again.
  • User navigates to a different page: We recalculate the OData $skip parameter, and call the backend again.
  • System changes the # of retrieved records: We recalculate the number of pages we have. This occurs basically whenever we call the backend.

 

Room for Improvement

There are small things we could have done to make it even better:

  • Put the icon for the full business partner list inside the input box, making it a custom component (something Bota did in her blog)
  • Add multi-selection and wildcard characters
  • Package it to make it more generic for any data entity

Also, I wanted to eliminate flashing when the user enters a search string, and there was a tradeoff between the flashing and the speed. I might change my calculus to make it faster.

I'll work on these. In the meantime, tell me what you thought of these techniques, including how you would improve them.

😸

entry.title: Kickstart Your Developer Journey – Get SAP-Certified in Low-Code/No-Code
entry.content:
New to development? No problem! SAP offers a certification and learning resources that help you build real business apps, workflows, and user experiences — without needing to be a coding expert. Using tools like SAP Build Apps, Work Zone, and Process Automation, you’ll be surprised how much you can do just by dragging, dropping, and configuring.

 

Simple Steps to Get Certified

 

Step 1: Learn at Your Own Pace Follow these beginner-friendly learning paths:

  • SAP Build Apps: Build apps visually without needing to write code. Learn how to connect data, create user-friendly pages, and define app behavior.
  • SAP Build Work Zone: Set up a digital workspace where users can access their apps and content in one place.
  • SAP Build Process Automation: Learn how to build simple workflows and automation tools to save time and reduce manual work.

Step 2: Practice What You Learn You’ll try a real-world simulation using everything you’ve learned. This hands-on practice is required before taking the certification exam and helps boost your confidence.

Step 3: Take the Certification Exam Once you feel ready, book your exam. Passing it proves your skills and gives you an official SAP Certification — a great addition to your resume!

 

Want to Keep Growing?

 

  • Watch tutorials on YouTube from SAP Developer Advocates.
  • Join local SAP CodeJam events to meet and learn from other developers.
  • Subscribe to SAP Learning Hub for more guided learning from SAP experts.

 

Whether you're starting your career or switching to tech, this certification is a great way to get hands-on with real business tools — and build your future.

entry.title: Export Data to Excel in SAP Build Apps Using JavaScript and Flow Functions
entry.content:
In this blog post, we’ll walk through how to implement Excel file export functionality in SAP Build Apps using a base64-encoded string. This use case is particularly useful when you're working with data returned from a backend API in base64 format—such as when exporting filtered reports or datasets.

Upon applying filters and invoking the backend API, the response returns the Excel file encoded in base64. This string is then stored in a Page Variable, decoded using a JavaScript logic block, and converted into a Blob URL. The Blob URL allows the app to seamlessly trigger a file download, giving users a smooth and intuitive experience.


Step-by-Step Implementation

Step 1: Create a Page Variable

Create a Page Variable to store the base64-encoded string returned by your backend API.

Step 2: Add a JavaScript Block

In the Logic Editor, drag in a JavaScript block and pass the base64 string to it as an input.
Set the output of the JavaScript block to type URL (Any Protocol).

Paste the following code into the JavaScript block:

 

// Helper: create Blob URL instead of data: URL
function createBlobURL(base64String, mimeType = "application/octet-stream") {
    const byteCharacters = atob(base64String);
    const byteNumbers = new Array(byteCharacters.length);
    for (let i = 0; i < byteCharacters.length; i++) {
        byteNumbers[i] = byteCharacters.charCodeAt(i);
    }
    const byteArray = new Uint8Array(byteNumbers);
    
    const blob = new Blob([byteArray], { type: mimeType });
    return URL.createObjectURL(blob);
}

// Example usage:
const base64Data = inputs.base64Data;
const mimeType = inputs.mimeType || "application/vnd.openxmlformats-officedocument.spreadsheetml.sheet";

const blobURL = createBlobURL(base64Data, mimeType);
console.log(blobURL);

return { result: blobURL };

This function takes the base64-encoded string, decodes it, and converts it into a downloadable Blob URL that can be used in the subsequent download logic.

Step 3: Install Required Flow Functions

From the Marketplace, install the following two flow functions:

  • Download Files

  • Export to Downloads

Step 4: Design the Flow Logic

Connect the flow in the following sequence:
JavaScript Block → Download Files → Export to Downloads

This setup ensures the decoded file is first processed and then downloaded properly to the user’s device.

Step 5: Configure the Download Files Block

  • Set the Download URL input to the output of the JavaScript block (the Blob URL).

  • Configure the filename and other settings as required.

Step 6: Configure the Export to Downloads Block

  • Map the inputs of this block to the corresponding outputs of the Download Files block.

  • This will save the file to the user's local device through the export mechanism.

Final Result

Once the user triggers the flow (e.g., by clicking a button), the backend API is called, and the returned base64-encoded Excel file is converted and downloaded — all within the SAP Build Apps environment.

This approach offers a clean, no-code/low-code solution to implementing Excel export functionality, even when the application is consumed via SAP Build Workzone there won't be any issue in exporting the file.

entry.title: Mastering Complex SBPA Approvals : A Deep Dive into Wait Steps, Script Tasks, and API Integrations
entry.content:
Welcome back to our new blog series,  our previous blog series  delved into the intricacies of dynamic sequential approval workflows.

In this two-part series, my colleague @Adwait_Fadnavis  and I will explore some very critical business workflow  requirements  in detail using SAP Build Process Automation. 

Throughout this blog series, we will delve into the following critical business requirements:

Part 1 - Current Blog :Mastering Complex SBPA Approvals : A Deep Dive into Wait Steps, Script Tasks, and API Integrations

Part 2 : Demonstration with Complete end to end testing 

We will demonstrate how to use various SAP Build Process Automation tools to solve real-time challenges effectively.

This blog post addresses this complex requirement with detailed step-by-step instructions. You'll learn how to ensure workflows advance smoothly, even with  approval condition utilizing various innovative latest features such as: Wait Step with API Triggering , Workflow Context update via API etc.

Business Context and Problem Statement

While working on multiple SAP Build Process Automation projects, we have faced situations where workflows only proceed if all departments or approvers approve them unanimously.

If any approver rejects the proposal, the entire workflow is rejected . This creates a need for a parallel approval process, adhering to an "all-or-nothing" requirement, which SAP's standard solutions do not support.

In a below sample procurement workflow, the request is created and submitted. Both the Department Manager and Finance Department must approve it simultaneously. If either rejects, the workflow is terminated.

If both approve, the request goes to the Executive for final approval. The Executive's decision determines whether the request is processed or terminated.

Dynamic Number of Parallel Approval
Technical Solutioning & Design

In this process, we will create two workflows using SAP Build Process Automation’s Low Code/No Code approach.

Let’s refer to these as Workflow A (main workflow) and Workflow B.

Workflow A( Main Workflow): This is the main workflow, triggered with all input parameters, responsible for the overall business process flow.

Workflow B(Secondary Workflow): This workflow handles the approval task. It receives the Approval ID, total number of levels, and current level. If the final approval is granted, it triggers a wait step API  in Workflow A to proceed to the next level. If more approvals are needed, it sends the Approval ID to the next level.

 
Technical Design Steps for Workflow A:
 
  1. Trigger Workflow: The workflow is initiated with input parameters.
  2. Decision Creation: A decision step is created to determine the number of approvals require. 

3. Script Task: This step determines the total number of approvals and the current approval level.

$.context.custom.doneapprovalcount = 0;
$.context.custom.currentcount = 0;
$.context.custom.subwfdefinationid = "Your Secondaray Workflow ID"; // replace with your secondary workflow id
$.context.custom.totalapprovalcount = $.context.decision_getAppprovers_1.Approvers.length;
$.context.custom.triggeredsubprocessids = [];
​
  • Condition Check: If the current level matches the total required approvals, A wait step will be created to wait for the completion. If not, Workflow B is triggered to initiate the approval task.

  • Trigger Workflow B: Workflow B sends the work item to the respective user for approval.
  • Wait Step API : This critical step waits for all parallel approvals to be completed. Once done, the dummy decision is triggered by Workflow B. This is very interesting and latest features
    1. Create a Wait Step with API as follows. After Deployment it will event will create the API End Point which will used to trigger from secondary workflow B .      
    2. Execution ID is the Parent Workflow ID.
    3. Upload the API specification and create the action for this
    4.  Also make sure to create the API key which will be used to trigger it from secondary workflow B.

Technical Design Steps for Workflow B  (Triggered via Workflow A)

  1. Trigger from Workflow A : Workflow B starts when Workflow A reaches a certain point to manage approval tasks separately and in parallel to the main workflow.

  2. Send Approval Task: The approval task is sent to the current level approver to obtain necessary approvals at each level before proceeding.
  3. On Approval: The system retrieves instance details and updates the approval count to keep track of completed approvals and update the workflow status.  
  4. sample code
$.context.custom.approvedcount = $.context.action_get_getV1WorkflowInstancesWorkflowInstanceIdContext_6.result.custom.doneapprovalcount + 1;
  • Check Count: The system checks if all required approvals are obtained:
    • If all approvals are done, the workflow proceeds to the next step.
    • If not all approvals are done This ensures the workflow only proceeds once all approvals are obtained
  •  Update Parent Workflow A Approval Action : increment the update count. created a custom action. If all the approvals not done, then update the approval count via custom action. (refer our previous blog how to create action for workflow API)   
  • Retrieve Task ID & Trigger Wait API trigger wait step ( API) in Workflow A to signal that the approval process is complete / Reject  and it can proceed.
    • Now come to most crucial part of the Development: Trigger the wait step via API
    • Created a custom action project  for the wait step api end point.
    • Here is the Input mapping for the API call. Needs to provide the API Key and Parent ID.
    • It will trigger the wait step in workflow A to approve / move forward the workflow . 
 
In the upcoming blog post - Demonstration with complete end to end testing  , @Adwait_Fadnavis  will delve into the complete end to end testing for these which is very critical to understand the whole development flow.
 
Stay tuned for a comprehensive guide that will enhance your understanding and streamline your Development  process.

Regards,

Mohit Bansal,

SAP Mentor. SAP BTP Solution Architect

entry.title: Unlocking the Future: How SAP Build Stands Out in Application Development
entry.content:
SAP Build stands out in the application development market due to its unique combination of low-code/no-code capabilities, deep integration with SAP ecosystems, AI-driven features, and focus on enterprise-grade scalability and governance. Below is a detailed analysis of why SAP Build differentiates itself from competitors like OutSystems, Mendix, or Microsoft Power Apps, emphasizing its strengths in the context of digital transformation and application development.

1. Unified Low-Code/No-Code Platform

  • Comprehensive Suite: SAP Build integrates three core components—SAP Build Apps, SAP Build Process Automation, and SAP Build Work Zone—into a single platform, enabling end-to-end development of applications, process automation, and business sites. Unlike competitors that often focus on one aspect (e.g., app development or automation), SAP Build provides a holistic solution, reducing the need for multiple tools.
  • Citizen Developer Empowerment: Its intuitive drag-and-drop interface and prebuilt templates allow business users with minimal technical expertise to create enterprise-grade applications. This democratizes development, enabling faster prototyping and reducing dependency on specialized developers, which competitors like OutSystems also offer but with less seamless SAP integration.

Standout Factor: The unified platform lowers the learning curve and streamlines workflows, making it ideal for businesses seeking rapid development without fragmented toolsets.

2. Deep Integration with SAP Ecosystem

  • SAP BTP Foundation: Built on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), SAP Build seamlessly integrates with SAP S/4HANA, SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Ariba, and other SAP solutions. This ensures a single source of truth, real-time data access, and compatibility with SAP’s clean core strategy, which minimizes technical debt during upgrades.
  • Extensibility: The Extensibility Wizard (introduced at SAP TechEd 2024) simplifies customization for SAP S/4HANA Cloud and is planned for SAP SuccessFactors, enabling tailored solutions without complex coding. Competitors like Mendix or Salesforce Lightning require additional integration layers to achieve similar SAP connectivity.
  • Third-Party Integration: SAP Build supports integration with non-SAP systems (e.g., Salesforce, Microsoft Dynamics) via SAP Integration Suite, with event-driven architecture planned for Q4 2025, enhancing real-time data flows.

Standout Factor: Native integration with SAP systems and support for hybrid environments make SAP Build the preferred choice for organizations heavily invested in SAP, unlike general-purpose platforms that require custom connectors.

3. AI-Driven Innovation

  • Joule Studio: SAP Build leverages AI through Joule Studio, enabling the creation of AI agents for predictive analytics, process automation, and intelligent decision-making. For example, it can automate complex workflows like invoice matching or predict inventory needs, a feature less prevalent in platforms like Appian or ServiceNow.
  • Embedded Intelligence: Integration with SAP AI Core allows developers to embed machine learning models into applications, enhancing functionality like demand forecasting or anomaly detection without external tools.
  • Natural Language Processing: Joule’s conversational AI simplifies user interactions, making app development and process automation accessible to non-technical users.

Standout Factor: AI-driven capabilities, tightly integrated with SAP’s enterprise data, provide a competitive edge over platforms with generic AI tools, delivering context-aware solutions for business-specific challenges.

4. Enterprise-Grade Scalability and Governance

  • Scalability: Built on SAP BTP’s cloud infrastructure, SAP Build supports enterprise-scale deployments with high availability and performance. It handles large-scale transformations, such as SAP S/4HANA migrations, with minimal latency, unlike smaller platforms like Bubble, which are better suited for startups.
  • Governance and Compliance: SAP Build includes built-in governance frameworks ensuring GDPR, SOC 2, and other compliance standards, critical for industries like finance or healthcare. This contrasts with platforms like Zoho Creator, which may require additional configurations for enterprise compliance.
  • Clean Core Strategy: SAP Build aligns with RISE with SAP’s clean core principles, ensuring extensions are upgradable and maintainable, reducing long-term costs compared to platforms like OutSystems, where customizations can lead to technical debt.

Standout Factor: Robust governance and scalability make SAP Build a trusted choice for large enterprises with complex regulatory and scalability needs.

5. Rapid Time-to-Value

  • Accelerated Development: SAP Build’s low-code approach reduces development time by 50-70% compared to traditional coding, as seen in case studies like Open Grid Europe, which achieved 50% faster onboarding using SAP Build Apps. Prebuilt templates and reusable components further speed up deployment.
  • Process Automation: SAP Build Process Automation combines RPA and workflow management, reducing manual tasks by up to 80% (e.g., financial close processes). This is faster than competitors like UiPath, which focus primarily on RPA without integrated app development.
  • Guided Methodologies: Integration with SAP Activate and SAP Signavio ensures structured implementation, minimizing project risks and accelerating time-to-value.

Standout Factor: The combination of low-code development, automation, and guided methodologies delivers faster ROI, particularly for SAP-centric transformations, compared to platforms with longer setup times.

6. Enhanced Collaboration and User Experience

  • Business-IT Collaboration: SAP Build bridges the gap between business and IT teams through shared development environments and visual tools, reducing miscommunication. For example, business users can prototype apps, while IT ensures governance, unlike Mendix, where IT involvement is often heavier.
  • SAP Build Work Zone: Provides role-based, personalized portals with SAP Fiori integration, improving user adoption by 25-40% (SAP benchmarks). This contrasts with platforms like Microsoft Power Apps, which offer less tailored UX for SAP environments.
  • Community and Support: SAP’s global partner ecosystem (e.g., EY, AG) and SAP Community provide extensive training and support, ensuring successful adoption compared to smaller platforms with limited ecosystems.

Standout Factor: Enhanced collaboration and user-centric design drive higher adoption rates, making SAP Build ideal for organizations prioritizing user engagement.

7. Competitive Positioning

Compared to key competitors:

  • OutSystems: Strong in low-code but lacks deep SAP integration and clean core alignment.
  • Mendix: Offers robust low-code features but requires more effort for SAP connectivity and compliance.
  • Microsoft Power Apps: Excels in Microsoft ecosystems but is less optimized for SAP environments.
  • ServiceNow: Focuses on IT service management, with limited app development flexibility compared to SAP Build’s comprehensive suite.

SAP Build’s tight integration with SAP BTP, AI capabilities, and focus on enterprise needs give it an edge for organizations leveraging SAP systems or pursuing large-scale digital transformations.

8. Real-World Impact

  • Open Grid Europe: Extended SAP S/4HANA Cloud with SAP Build, achieving 50% faster onboarding and 20% reduced invoicing time.
  • Multinational Manufacturer: Used SAP Build with EY to standardize processes, improving efficiency across functions within 12 months.
  • Utilities Sector: Leveraged SAP Build for metering and billing apps, reducing process steps and enhancing real-time visibility.

Conclusion

SAP Build stands out in the application development market due to its unified low-code/no-code platform, deep SAP integration, AI-driven innovation, and enterprise-grade scalability. Its ability to accelerate development, automate processes, and ensure compliance while fostering collaboration makes it a leader for organizations undergoing SAP-centric or hybrid digital transformations. For businesses invested in SAP ecosystems or seeking rapid, scalable solutions, SAP Build delivers unmatched value, positioning it as a top choice in the competitive low-code market.

SAP Build  SAP AI Services SAP Cloud Application Programming Model

entry.title: Manage SAP Build projects as part of your enterprise architecture
entry.content:
Recently, I transitioned from SAP Landscape Management to the product management team of SAP LeanIX. I landed in a fantastic team already hard at work on the integration between SAP LeanIX and SAP Build, and I was fortunate enough to help bring the first release across the finish line, which was announced last week.

Now, you can seamlessly connect your SAP Build instances with your SAP LeanIX workspaces, enabling automatic discovery of your SAP Build projects. This empowers enterprise architects to model these projects as application fact sheets, integrating them directly into their daily workflows within SAP LeanIX.

SAP Build is described as a "unified application development and process automation solution, enabling personalization and efficiency at scale." (source) It's a vital part of our customers' IT landscapes, complementing their existing SAP solutions. Consequently, the custom projects setup within SAP Build represent the unique, differentiating elements of their landscapes. Managing these projects alongside other SAP and non-SAP solutions within SAP LeanIX is a natural and essential next step.

Connecting the Dots

Rather than diving deep into the documentation, let me give you a quick overview of how to regularly discover your SAP Build projects within your SAP LeanIX workspace.

You'll need an instance of SAP Build Process Automation (even if you primarily use other SAP Build components) and an instance of SAP Cloud Management Service within your SAP BTP subaccount. The Cloud Management Service provides the context to the SAP BTP Global and Subaccount. Using service keys for these two instances, you can configure the new "SAP Build" integration within the admin area of SAP LeanIX.  Once you complete the onboarding wizard, your SAP Build projects will be automatically discovered and regularly updated.

The SAP Discovery inbox will present you with a list of all discovered projects. From there, you can link them to existing fact sheets or create new ones. The integration intelligently suggests the following fact sheet types:

  • Application: The project itself
  • IT Component: The technology used within the project (e.g. SAP Build Code)
  • Platform: SAP BTP, your global account, and the subaccount
  • Provider: SAP

I'm eager to hear your thoughts on this new integration! Does this address a pain point in your enterprise architecture work? What other challenges are you facing when managing extensions to your SAP solution portfolio?  Share your feedback in the comments below or on our roadmap item!

entry.title: REST API Integration and Data Visualization in SAP Build Apps
entry.content:
1.Project Creation in SAP Build Apps

To begin integrating and displaying data from a REST API in SAP Build Apps, the first step is to create a new project. Follow these steps:

Step-by-Step Guide:

  1. Log in to your SAP Build Apps account using your SAP BTP credentials.
  2. Navigate to the Home Page:
    • Once logged in, you will land on the SAP Build Apps dashboard.
  3. Click on ‘Create Project’:
    • On the dashboard, locate and click the "Create Project" button. This will open a project creation wizard.
  4. Select the Project Type:
    • Choose “Application” (usually the Web and Mobile App option) to build a UI-based application.
    • Click “Next” to proceed.

  • Now select the frontend option and click on next button.

  • Select the Web and Mobile applications option and click on next.

    5.Enter Project Details:

    1. Project Name: Enter a meaningful name for your project (e.g., "REST API Integration App").
    2. Optionally, you can also provide a description to document the purpose of the project.

    6.Create the Project:

    1. Click “Create” or “Finish” (depending on UI version).
    2. The app builder canvas will open, allowing you to start designing your application interface and logic.

2. REST API Integration in Build app.

To connect your SAP Build App with an external REST API and use its data, you need to configure it using the Universal REST API Integration feature. Follow the steps below to complete this process:

Step-by-Step Guide to Integrate a REST API:

Open Your Project in SAP Build Apps

  • Once your application project is created, open it to launch the Build Editor (the design and logic workspace).

Go to the Integrations Panel

  • Open Integrations panel. This section is where you can manage data resources, including integrations with external services.

Create a New Data Resource

  • Click on the “Create Data Entity” button.
  • From the dropdown list of available data integration options, choose:
    • “Universal REST API Integration”

Configure the REST API Connection
You will now be prompted to fill in the details for your API:

  • Resource Name: Enter a name for your API resource (e.g., UserAPI, ProductsAPI).
  • Base URL: Provide the base URL of the REST API you want to connect to.

Example: https://restcountries.com/v3.1/all

Test the API Connection

  • After configuring each endpoint, click the “Test” button to verify the API response.
  • If successful, you will see the response schema, which will be used for data binding in your app.

Save the Configuration

  • Once your API endpoints are set up and tested, click “Save” to finalize the data integration.

  • Now added REST API details displays like below.

3. Declaring Data Variables to Map API Data to the UI

After successfully integrating a REST API in SAP Build Apps, you may notice that you cannot directly bind the API response properties to the UI components. To resolve this, you need to declare data variables, which act as a bridge between your API data and the UI.

Step-by-Step Guide to Declare Data Variables

  1. Open the Variables Tab

  • In the top-right panel of the Build Editor, click on the “Variables” tab.

  2. Select ‘Data Variables’

  • In the variables panel, you’ll see different types of variables:
    • Page Variables – for temporary, page-specific values.
    • App Variables – for global values across the app.
    • Data Variables – for storing and working with data from integrated APIs or data sources.
  • Click on “Data Variables” to expand that section.

  3. Add a Data Variable

  • Click the “+ Add Data Variable” button.

  4. Select the Data Type

  • Choose the appropriate type of data variable based on your use case:
    • Collection – If you're fetching a list of records (e.g., list data).
    • Single Data Record – If you're fetching or working with a single item (e.g., a product detail).

  5. Save the Variable

  • Once configured, click “Save” to finalize the data variable.

4. Designing Build App User Interface

Once your REST API is integrated and data variables are configured, the next step is to design your application’s user interface (UI). This is where you define how the app will visually display data and interact with users.

Step-by-Step Guide to Design the UI

  • Open the User Interface Editor and set page title.

5. Binding Data to List Control in SAP Build Apps

After designing your UI and creating data variables, the next step is to map your data to a List component. This allows your app to dynamically display items (such as users, products, or any collection) from the REST API.

Step-by-Step Guide to Bind Data to a List Component

  1. Add a List Component to the Page

 Open the UI Canvas (User Interface Editor).

From the Component Library, drag the “List” component onto your page layout.

  2. Select the List Component

  • Click on the List component to open its Properties panel on the right-hand side.

  3. Configure Repeating Items (Repeat With)

  • In the Properties panel, locate the setting labelled “Repeat With”.
  • This defines the data source for the repeating list items.

  4. Choose a Data Variable

  • Click the dropdown next to Repeat With.
  • A list of available Data Variables will be shown — select the one you created for the API data (e.g., Current countries data).

  5. Save the Configuration

  • After selecting the data variable, click the “Save” button to apply the binding.
  • Now, the List is set to dynamically repeat and render items based on the API data.

Display Data inside List Items

  •  Now we have to map the list control primary and secondary variables from data variables option shown like below.

  • Here I have selected the current countries as primary label and country codes selected for secondary label as shown like below.

6.Previewing and Running the App in SAP Build Apps
Once the data is successfully mapped to the List component and your UI is complete, it's time to preview the application and see how it functions in real-time.

  1. Save Your Work

  • After completing all data bindings and UI configurations, ensure that you click the “Save” button (usually located in the top-right corner of the editor).
  • This saves your project and prepares it for preview.

  2. Click the “Preview” Button

  • At the top toolbar, click the “Preview” button.
  • This opens the Preview panel, where you can choose how and where to run your app.


  3. Select Your Application

  • In the Web Preview Portal, find and select your app from the list of available applications.
    • Look for the name you gave during the project creation step (e.g., User Directory App, Product Catalog).
    • Click the “Open” button next to your app.


 Finally View Our Application in the Browser

Thanks,

Spandana.

entry.title: SAP BTP Global Account audit logs using SAP BTP Auditlog service, SAP Build Apps and SAP Ai Core
entry.content:
Let’s assume you are responsible for your company’s global account on the SAP BTP and would like to know what happens in the global account itself and in the subaccounts, right? I’m going to show you one of the practical and (in my opinion) giving some fun solutions.

Let’s start with the BTP basics. The platform gathers and stores crucial information about what happened in form of audit logs. These logs are being gathered and stored on two levels: global account level and subaccount level. Access to the audit logs on the subaccount level is simple – you can use the SAP BTP service called Audit Log Viewer. It is free of charge as per date of writing. But situation on the global account level is different – there is no way to run any service directly in the global account, so you can’t use Audit Log Viewer here. But your logs are still there – you just need to expose them via REST API and then access them – again via the REST API.

 

Exposing the global account logs.

Here we need one of the SAP BTP services, the SAP AuditLog service. Keep in mind that there are two versions of this service: free and paid. The free version is enough if standard log retention period of 90 days is enough. But if you want to increase the retention period over 90 days, you need the paid, premium version. You also need the premium version if you want to store logs generated by your own applications, running in the SAP BTP. More information here: Retention of Audit Data written from SAP BTP Applications and Services and here: Retention of Audit Data written from Customer’s BTP Applications

To run any SAP BTP service, first we need a subaccount for this service (or services). I strongly recommend creating one subaccount, dedicated just to the platform management. I would call it “technical” subaccount. This “technical” subaccount would serve purely for SAP BTP management and monitoring purposes – no business-related solutions should be placed here.

First thing to do after subaccount creation should be establishing trust with your IAS (if you use IAS, what I strongly recommend) and assigning “Subaccount Administrator” role collection to the appropriate people.

Then, on the global account level, assign the Auditlog Management Service, “central” plan to the “technical” subaccount. Please note it must be “central” plan and not any other.

Go to your “technical” subaccount and find the “Service Marketplace”. In the Service Marketplace, find the Auditlog service and under three dots select “Create”. Now it is important to create instance of this service with “central” plan – this is the only plan allowing access to the global account audit logs.

When service instance is created, click the arrow on the right-hand end of the instance line, find section called “Service Keys” and press “Create”. The only information you need to provide in this step is how you want to name the new service key – nothing more.

When service key is generated, you can access the Auditlog Management service via the REST API – right now click the tree dots on the right-hand end of the service key line and select “download”. This will give you the Auditlog service’s service key in form of “txt” file, but in fact the internal structure of this file is JSON, so if you change the file extension from “txt” to “json”, you will see the service key JSON-formatted in any tool supporting this format. You will need this file in a moment. But before you can access the logs, you need to assign correct privileges to you and/or anybody else who should have access to the audit logs of the global account. The Auditlog Management service is unique in the way that it doesn’t provide ready to use role collection – instead it provides just a role “Audilog_Auditor”. You must add this role to one of the existing role collections or create your own role collection, add this role and assign this new role collection to the appropriate people – or preferably, map them to the IAS groups of users.

Destination definition.

Regardless of whether you use a Pro-Code or No-Code approach, the SAP BTP Destination will be very helpful—especially for authentication. Therefore, we’ll begin by defining the SAP BTP Destination that points to the SAP Auditlog service. Go to the SAP BTP Cockpit, to the subaccount where your application development environment is running. If you have no access to this subaccount or have no “Subaccount Administrator” nor at least “Destination Administrator” rights for this subaccount, you need to find someone who has such privileges, and this parson must perform the next action: define SAP BTP destination to the Auditlog service.

Creating the destination is a standard and easy process – you just need to provide information found in the Auditlog service’s service key you already downloaded, like service address, authentication type, authentication address, client id and client credentials. But for the destination to work properly in SAP Build Apps, we need also to define some “Additional Properties”.

The data for SAP BTP Destination:

  • Name: “Central_Audit_Log_Service” – it is up to you how you name it, but the name should be meaningful, and you should be able to tell what the purpose of this destination is just based on its name even after a year or so.
  • Type: HTTP
  • Proxy Type: Internet
  • URL: open the downloaded service key file and find the “url:” line. Note: this is the very first “url” you can see in the file. Copy the full address with “http://”, but without the quotation marks. It should look like this:
    https://auditlog-management.xxxx.xxxx.xxxx.ondemand.com
  • Authentication: OAuth2ClientCredentials
  • Client ID: copy the content of the “clientid” line you can find in the “uaa” section of the service key – again without the quotation marks
  • Client Secret: copy the content of the “clientsecret” line you can find in the “uaa” section of the service key – again without the quotation marks
  • Token Service URL: here you have to combine the content of the “url” line you can find in the “uaa” section – again without the quotation marks – with the following: “/oauth/token”.
    Note 1: do NOT use the first “url” from the service key file here! In this field you must use the “url” you find INSIDE the “uaa” section.
    Note 2: the full Token Service address should look like this: https://xxxxx.xxxxxx.xxxx.xxxxxxx.com/oauth/token
  • Token Service URL Type: Dedicated

Additional Properties:

The absolute minimum is the following:

  • BuildApps.Enabled = true
  • BuildApps.ApiType = rest

On top, I would suggest adding the following, to be able to use the same destination in the future in other SAP Build tools and for other purposes, like automation, for instance:

  • sap.applicationdevelopment.actions.enabled = true
  • sap.processautomation.enabled = true
  • MobileEnabled = true

Save the destination and check the connection – it should give response like this:

 

 

Building the application.

I recommend using SAP Build Apps for this purpose as it is the simples, fastest and most funny way to achieve our goal.

I assume here, that you already have access to SAP Build Apps or at least you know how to get it. If not, please ask your SAP Account Executive or SAP partner.

Create a new SAP Build Apps project as usual. Ensure that the SAP BTP Authentication is enabled. The application pages structure is up to you – for example you could put the list of log records immediately on the starting page or if you prefer, you can make starting page just for information, describing application purpose and put here a button to open a new page, the one actually showing the list of log records – you can do it your own way. Importantly, you should create a page that displays a list of records. You can use any existing “List” artefact, but I prefer to do it my own way, using a row, which “repeats” with output from the Auditlog service call.

 

Task 1: Getting access to the Auditlog data.

Thanks to the destination we prepared in the previous step, it will be easy task:

  1. Go to the “Integrations” tab
  2. In the “Integrations” section press the blue button “ADD INTEGRATION” – new page will open
  3. In the section “SAP Systems”, press the “BTP DESTINATIONS” button
  4. You should see the “REST API Endpoints” section and your SAP BTP destination to the Auditlog service you created during the preparation phase (“Central_Audit_Log_Sertvice” in my case) – select it
  5. Click “INSTALL INTEGRATION” in the top right corner of the screen
    This would be enough to send requests to the Auditlog service via the “HTTP Destination Request” function block and get answers, but you need a bit more: you need a data structure, identical with the structure of the answer, to repeat the list rows with.
  6. Press the “Add REST API Data Entity” button – an “Add REST API Data Entity” form will appear.
  7. Fill the form this way:
    1. Name: records
    2. Autogenerate configuration: selected
    3. Entity path within the API: /auditlog/v2/auditlogrecords
    4. Enable Capabilities: select only “list” – no other capability can be used in case of the Auditlog service
  8. Press the “Add” button
    After a few seconds you should see your “records” entity with auto-generated 11 fields. These fields were automatically read from the service thanks to the SAP BTP Destination you defined during the preparation phase.
  9. Select the “list” capability and press the “Run Test” button. If everything was done correctly so far, you should get in a few seconds the “Status: OK (200)” response above the black window and list of records inside the black window. If this is the case, you can now start shaping the UI of your app. Otherwise you need to check all the previous steps in search of mistake.

Now have a look at the list of records, visible in the black window. You can see here the structure of the answer from the Auditlog service. It is a list of objects. Object has 11 properties – the same as auto generated fields in the “records” entity. But there is a difference: the last field of the “records” entity named “message” is of “Text” type, while in the actual response it is an object with several properties. In case of a simple application, just showing logs, you should leave it as it is, but note that there is a room for further improvements of your app in the future. Leaving it as it is, you can display the “message” object as plain text, but with some work it is possible to get direct access to each property inside the “message” object in the API response. But this is outside of the scope of this article.

 

Task 2: The start page.

I recommend here creating three pages:

  • Star page
  • The log listing page
  • The record details page

Creating an app, you get one page immediately – it is your start page, so you just need to create next two pages and name them in a meaningful way, something like “List of records” and “Record details”.

So, we have:

  • “Home Page” – it is our start page
  • “List of records” – it is the page where we will see list of records and will select one of them for detailed view
  • “Record details” – it is the page where we will display all the record’s details and eventually will add interpretation done by the AI

 

For the time being, we will put just two things on the start page:

  • The “Title” component for short explanation of the app purpose
  • A “Button”, to open the records list page

We could show the list of records immediately on the start page, but making separate start page will allow us in the future to easily add new functions, without messing with the list of log records.

Put the text you want to display to app user at the start and the “Button”. Select the button and change its label to something like “Show records”. Open the logic canvas and put “Open page” flow function on it. Connect output of the “Component tap” with the input of the “Open page”. Select the “Open page” flow function and in the right-hand part of the screen, in “PROPRTIES” tab, select the “List of records” page to open (assuming you named so your page which will show the list of records).

Press “Save” in the top-right corner of the screen.

 

Task 3: Displaying the records.

The logic will work like this:

  1. Show the “Spinner”
  2. Get the records from the Auditlog service and put it in the data variable
  3. Hide the “Spinner”
  4. Show the records

 

Select the “List of records” page (or whatever you named your log list page).

Step 1:  The “Spinner”

First put the “Spinner” on the empty page, to make waiting for logs to appear a bit more pleasant.

We will need a variable to control visibility of the “Spinner”. As this variable matters only on this page, we will make it a “Page variable”.

  • Having the “List of records” page open, click the “Variables” tab at the very top of the screen.
  • Click “PAGE VARIABLES” on the left-hand side
  • Click “ADD PAGE VARIABLE” icon at the center of the screen
  • Select “From scratch”
  • Name the variable “PgVarSpinnerVisibility”
  • Change the “Variable value type” to “True/false”
  • Ensure that the “Initial value” is set to “False”
  • Save

Come back to the “User Interface” Tab at the top of the screen and select the “Spinner” you placed on the UI canvas and:

  • Change size to “large”
  • Open “ADVANCED PROPERTIES”
  • Click the square icon just below the “Visible” icon – dialog opens
  • Select “Data and Variables”
  • Select “Page variable”
  • Select the “PgVarSpinnerVisibility” variable you defined a minute ago
  • Save in the dialog
  • Switch to the “LAYOUT” tab
  • Open “POSITION” and select the icon to align it horizontally to the middle
  • Save in the top-right corner of screen

 

Step 2: The data to display

Then we need to define a data variable, based on the “records” entity we have in the integration. To do so, still having the “List of records” page open:

  • click on the “Variables” tab at the top of the screen
  • click “DATA VARIABLES” on the left side of the screen
  • click “ADD DATA VARIABLE” next to the plus in the circle sign
  • select “records”
  • change the default variable name in the “Data variable name” field of the right-side properties section to something meaningful, like “DataVarListOfRecords”
  • ensure that the “Data variable type” is set to “Collection of data records”
  • having selected the “DataVarListOfRecords”, open the “Logic canvas”
  • cut the link between “Page mounted” event and the “Get record collection” flow function
  • Insert here the “Set page variable” flow function – connect its input to the exit of the “Page mounted” event and connect its exit to the input of the “Get record collection” flow function.
  • Select the “Set page variable” flow function
  • Select the “PgVarSpinnerVisibility” under the “Variable name” label
  • Select “True” under the “Assigned value” label
  • Add second “Set page variable” flow function
  • Connect its input to the exit of the “Set data variable” output
  • Select the second “Set page variable” flow function
  • Select the “PgVarSpinnerVisibility” under the “Variable name” label
  • Select “False” under the “Assigned value” label
  • Save

The function flow should look like this:

 

 

 

Step 3: Define visual structure of the list of records.

You can use here any ready to use list, available in the “MARKETPLACE” section, but I prefer to shape the list using “Row” as this approach gives me the full control over what and how is displayed on the screen.

We will show here only three fields, but you can modify this structure any way you want.

  • Put the “Row” component on the UI canvas
  • Change layout of the “Row” to have three cells (do it in the right-hand section, “LAYOUT” tab)
  • Define width of each cell as 1

 

  • Put “Text” component in each cell of the row

In the future you can improve the look of this page by adding borders, backgrounds, headers etc, but now we are going just to display the list of records the simplest way.

Select the row. Note you must select entire row and not just e cell. The easiest way is to use the “TREE” view at bottom-right part of the screen.

 

 

With row selected, go to the “PROPERTIES” tab in the section above the tree view and click the square icon labeled “Repeat with”.

 

A dialog will open – select “Data and Variables”, then “Data variable” and then the data variable we defined just a few minutes ago (“DataVarListOfRecords”).

Click “Save” (in the dialog) and then again “Save” (top-right corner of screen).

We have “Text” component in each cell, so now we will connect each “Text” with proper data to display.

Select the first “Text” in the “Row” and in the right-hand “PROPERTIES” tab click the icon just below the “Content” label. Dialog opens – select “Data item in repeat”.

 

Ten select “current”. Find and select “time” and press “Save”.

Select the second “Text” in the “Row” and configure it the same way as the first one, but this time select “category”.

Select the third “Text” in the “Row” and configure it the same way as the first one, but this time select “tenant”.

Finally, press the “Save” button in the top-right corner of the screen to save the application.

The last thing we will add on this page is a “Button” to come back to the start page:

  • Place a “Button” just below the “Row” on the UI canvas
  • Change label of the button to “Back”
  • Format the button as you like using the “STYLE” and “LAYOUT” tabs on the right-hand side of the screen
  • Click the “arrow up” icon at the very bottom of the screen, named “Add logic to LIST OF RECORDS”. The text “LIST OF RECORDS” is the name of this page, so if you named the page differently, you would see your name of the page instead of the “LIST OF RECORDS”
  • Find “Navigate back” flow function in the “CORE” tab of the “LOGIC CANVAS” and place it next to the “EVENT Component tap” block on the logic canvas
  • Connect exit of the “Component tap” with the input of the “Navigate back” flow function
  • Save

 

 

Step 4: adding full view of the selected record

Now we will take care of the “Record details” page of our app. The Auditlog service does not allow for requesting just one record, based on its id (at the date of writing), so we will do all the data preparation work on the “List of records” page we already have running and then write the record data to the Application Variable to make it available to the “Record details” page, which in turn will be responsible for displaying the already prepared data.

The procedure will look like this:

  1. User clicks on the desired record in the displayed list
  2. App logic of the “List of records” page searches for the desired record in the data variable “DataVarListOfRecords”
  3. App logic of the “List of records” page writes the data of the record it found to the Application Variable
  4. App logic of the “List of records” page opens the “Record details” page
  5. The “Record details” page shows record details

Create the Application Variables

We will need two application variables.

  1. Go to the “Variables” tab
  2. Select “APP VARIABLES”
  3. Select “ADD APP VARIABLE”
  4. Select “From existing schema”
  5. Select “Entity”
  6. Select the entity we created in chapter “B. Application building.” paragraph “Preparation of the data structure for the list of records to repeat with”. We named this entity “records”
  7. Change name of the app variable to “AppVarSingleRecord”
  8. Select “ADD APP VARIABLE”
  9. Select “From scratch”
  10. Change name of the app variable to “AppVarMessageText”
  11. Make sure the “Variable value type” is “Text”
  12. Save

 

Activate the row, so clicking on any record activates the process of displaying its content

  1. Open the “User Interface” tab at the top of the screen
  2. Open the “List of records” page
  3. Select the “Row” – ensure you selected the row and not a single cell nor single text. Use the “TREE” view in the bottom-right corner of the screen for precise selection
  4. With “Row” selected, open the “LOGIC CANVAS”
  5. Drag to the logic canvas two “Set app variable” and one “Open page” flow functions.
  6. Connect all the flow function in one flow: “Component tap” -> “Set app variable” -> “Set app variable” -> “Open page”.
  7. First “Set app variable”:
    • “Variable name”: select “AppVarSingleRecord”
    • “Assigne value”:
      • click the square icon – dialog will open
      • select “Formula"
      • click on the formula line
      • delete the current formula
      • type “find_by” – two suggestions will show – double click the “FIND_BY_KEY”
      • highlight the “list” in the formula
      • select the “Data variables” on the left
      • double click the “DataVarListOfRecords”
      • highlight the “key” in the formula
      • type here “message_uuid” – this time type it WITH the quotation marks
      • highlight the “value” in the formula
      • select the “Currently repeated data item” on the left
      • double click the “repeated.current.message_uuid”
        The final formula should look like this:
        FIND_BY_KEY(data.DataVarListOfRecords, "message_uuid", repeated.current.message_uuid)
        if you name everything exactly like in my example, you can simply copy this formula and paste it in the formula field.
      • Save
  8. Second “Set app variable”:
    We want to show the “message” written in the log record, but its format makes it hard to read. We will make small but meaningful changes in the message format and this is the purpose of this flow function.
    1. “Variable name”: select “AppVarMessageText”
    2. “Assigne value”:
      • click the square icon – dialog will open
      • select “Formula”
      • click on the formula line
      • delete the current formula
      • put
        REPLACE_ALL(REPLACE_ALL(LEFT_STRIP(RIGHT_STRIP(appVars.AppVarSingleRecord.message, 1), 1),",","\n"),"\\","")
        as the formula – it removes the opening and closing brackets, relaces comas with new lines and removes backslashes
      • Save
  9. “Open page”: select “Record details” page to open
  10. Save

 

Build the UI of the “Record details” page

We already have the “Record details” page, but we need to put all the fields on it and connect them to the correct data sources. If we were to show just data entity, defined in the “Integrations” tab, we could use the AI for this task (assuming AI is enabled in your SAP Build environment). But we will not show the data entity – instead we will show content of the two application variables: “AppVarSingleRecord” and “AppVarMessageText”. So we need to design the page layout manually.

  1. Get familiar with structure of the AppVarSingleRecord application variable – note the data fields
  2. Open the “Record details” page
  3. Put a “Text” component on the UI canvas for each field of the variable
  4. For each “Text” component EXCEPT the one for “message” field do the following:
    1. select the “Text” component
    2. press the square icon just below the “Content” label in the “PROPERTIES” panel on the right-hand side – a dialog will open
    3. select “Data and variables”
    4. select “App variable”
    5. select “AppVarSingleRecord”
    6. select the data field you want to display using this “Text” component
    7. Save
  5. Select the “Text” component in which you want to display the message
    1. press the square icon just below the “Content” label in the “PROPERTIES” panel on the right-hand side – a dialog will open
    2. select “Data and variables”
    3. select “App variable”
    4. select “AppVarMessageText”
    5. Save
  6. Put a “Button” component at the end of the page and select it
  7. Open the logic canvas and drag here the “Navigate back” flow function and connect it to the “Component tap” event
  8. Save the application

Now you can use the “Preview” option in the top-right corner of the screen to test your application.

If the application works, now you can spend some time beautifying the application by:

  • Adding header row above the list of records in the “List of records” page
  • Adding additional, static texts as labels for dynamic text fields – here you can use rows for structured view
  • Adding containers and placing fields in the containers – to add visual structure to the pages
  • Manage borders, paddings and margins of the components
  • Manage color scheme

Finally, when you are happy with your app, go to the “Publish section, create build configuration, build the application and deploy.

 

Adding the date filters

As the application already works, we can see, that sometimes there is a lot of records to display. The Auditlog service’s API is limited: it can (as per date of writing) send back up to 500 records. You will find that quite often you would like the ability to define date range of log records to display.

Variables to store dates

We need to create in total four application variables to store the selected dates and to process them the way we need. Let’s create them right now:

Go to Variables -> APPLICATION VARIABLES and define the following variables:

  1. “DateFrom”
    • Variable value type: Date/time text (ISO8601)
  2. “DateTo”
    • Variable value type: Date/time text (ISO8601)
  3.  “DateFromTxt”
    • Variable value type: Text
    • Initial value: 0000-00-00T00:00:00
  4.  “DateToTxt”
    • Variable value type: Text
    • Initial value: 0000-00-00T00:00:00

 

UI modification

For simplicity, we will modify the “Home page” – our start page. We will add there two components: one for start date and the other one for end date. We will use ready to use “Date field”:

  1. Open the “Home page”
  2. Press “MARKETPLACE” in the UI components panel
  3. Search for “Date field” – at least three options will appear
  4. Select the option named just “Date field”
  5. Click “Install”
  6. Exit the “MARKETPLACE”
  7. Select “INSTALLED” in the UI components panel
  8. Find just installed “Date field” and drag it twice to the UI canvas – we need two of them
  9. Place both just above the already existing “Button”
  10. Select the topmost “Date field”
  11. Choose the “DateFrom” application variable in the “Selected value” property
  12. Type “Start date:” in the “Label” field
  13. Switch to the “LAYOUT” tab
  14. Expand the “WIDTH AND HEIGHT” section and select “Fit content”
  15. Scroll down to “POSITION” and select the icon to justify horizontally to the middle
  16. Scroll down to the “Z-index” and set it to “101”
  17. Select the lower “Date field”
  18. Choose the “DateTo” application variable in the “Selected value” property
  19. Type “End date:” in the “Label” field
  20. Switch to the “LAYOUT” tab
  21. Expand the “WIDTH AND HEIGHT” section and select “Fit content”
  22. Scroll down to “POSITION” and select the icon to justify horizontally to the middle
  23. Scroll down to the “Z-index” and set it to “100”

Now we will set the default values for both fields. Let’s assume that we want to see the current day’s log records by default.

  1. Click somewhere in the empty space of the “Home page” UI canvas
  2. Open the logic canvas
  3. Find “IF condition” flow function in the “CORE” section of the logic components and drag two instances to the logic canvas
  4. Find “Set app variable” and again drag two instances
  5. Connect inputs of both “IF condition” flow functions to the “Page mounted” event
  6. Connect exit of first “IF condition” flow function to the input of the first “Set app variable” flow function
  7. Connect exit of the second “IF condition” flow function to the input of the second “Set app variable” flow function
  8. Select first “IF condition” flow function
  9. Select “Formula” in the “Condition” field
  10. Put
    appVars.DateFromTxt=="0000-00-00T00:00:00"
    in the formula field
  11. Select second “IF condition” flow function
  12. Select “Formula” in the “Condition” field
  13. Put
    appVars.DateToTxt=="0000-00-00T00:00:00"
    in the formula field
  14. Select first “Set app variable” flow function
  15. Set “Variable name” to the application variable “DateFrom”
  16. Select “Formula” in the “Assigned value” field and put
    NOW()
    in the formula field
  17. Select second “Set app variable” flow function
  18. Set “Variable name” to the application variable “DateTo”
  19. Select “Formula” in the “Assigned value” field and put
    NOW()
    in the formula field – yes, we need the same value here
  20. Save the application

 

Data entity modification

We need to modify the data entity we defined in the “Integrations” tab, so let’s go there.

  1. Open the “Integrations” tab
  2. Select the “records” entity
  3. Scroll down to the very end of entity definition
  4. Find “Additional inputs”
  5. Add two additional inputs:
  6. “date_from” of type “Text”
  7. “date_to” of type “Text”

     



  8. Scroll up to the “Relative path and query” field
  9. Click it and replace the formula with:
    "/auditlog/v2/auditlogrecords?time_from="+query.additionalInputs.date_from+"&time_to="+query.additionalInputs.date_to
    this way we simply add two parameters to the REST API call and we do it the way that both parameters are set dynamically at the call based on the additional inputs we defined at the very bottom of the entity definition

     



  10. Note that now we see both additional inputs in the “Test” section of the “records” entity. If you want to test the entity now, you have to provide both inputs in the form: YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS. For example 2025-06-13T00:00:00 for “date_from” and 2025-06-13T23:59:59 for “date_to”.

     



  11. Save the application
  12. Go to the “User interface” tab and open the “List of records” page
  13. Go to the “Variables” tab and select the “DATA VARIABLES” section
  14. Select the “DataVarListOfRecords” – now you see the two additional inputs
  15. Connect the “date_from” input to the “DateFromTxt” application variable
  16. Connect the “date_to” input to the “DateToTxt” application variable



17. Save the application

“Home page” button function modification
