The Auditlog service API expects date/time to be sent in exact format and does not tolerate any differences, so we must transform the Date/time value we receive from the “Date field” components to exactly the format expected by the API.

  1. Open the “User Interface” tab
  2. Open the “Home page”
  3. Select the button
  4. Open the logic canvas
  5. Cut the connection between the “Component tap” event and the “Open page” flow function
  6. Drag two instances of the “Set app variable” function flow to the logic canvas
  7. Connect everything in single flow, with “Open page” flow function at the very end of the flow
  8. Select first “Set app variable” function flow
  9. Select “DateFromTxt” in the “Variable Name”
  10. Select “Formula” in the “Assigned value” field
  11. Put
    SUBSTRING(appVars.DateFrom, 0, 11)+"00:00:00"
    in the formula field - we simply cut off everything what is after “T” in the “YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS” format. We need to do so as the format we receive from the “Date field” can vary and it contains milliseconds and can contain additional signs. Then we add the fixed time. In the future we could potentially make the time an additional, dynamic factor in the filters, though.
  12. Select second “Set app variable” function flow
  13. Select “DateToTxt” in the “Variable Name”
  14. Select “Formula” in the “Assigned value” field
  15. Put
    SUBSTRING(appVars.DateTo, 0, 11)+"23:59:59"
    in the formula field
  16. Save the application
  17. Test the application in the “Preview”
  18. If everything works, build and deploy

 

 

Adding Artificial Intelligence for log message interpretation

Messages included in the logs can be difficult to read, understand and interpret. Adding AI might help a bit.

 

Setting up the AI in the SAP AI Core

Here I assume you already have access to the SAP AI Core and either have privileges needed to setup the AI deployment or you already have access to the AI deployment you can use in the application.

In short, when you start with the SAP AI Core:

  1. You have to create a resource group, where your resources, like configurations and deployments, will be stored.
  2.  You need to create a configuration of the LLM you will use.
  3. Create a deployment of your AI LLM, based on the configuration from point 2.

 

Creating the SAP BTP Destination

To proceed further we need the following information:

  1. SAP AI Launchpad: copy the name of the resource group you use – my resource group is named “default”
  2. SAP AI Launchpad: open the deployment you will use and copy its URL:

 

 

  1. SAP BTP Cockpit: you need the service key of the SAP AI Core service – more precisely you need authentication url, client id and client secret.

After gathering all the information, we need to define the destination in the SAP BTP subaccount, where SAP Build is deployed, pointing to the SAP AI Core’s AI deployment we will use.

Name: it is up to you. I use ChatGPT4o, so in my case the destination name is AI_Core_GPT4o

Type: HTTP

Proxy Type: Internet

URL: this is the url of the AI deployment, you copied this url in the SAP AI Launchpad

Authentication: OAuth2ClientCredentials

Client ID: copy from the SAP AI Core service’s service key

Client Secret: copy from the SAP AI Core service’s service key

Token service URL: this is the “url” value from the service key + /oauth/token – it should look like:

https://xxxxx.xxxxxxxx.xxxxxx.xxxxxxx.com/oauth/token

 

Token Service URL Type: Dedicated

 

 

And some additional properties:

The minimum:

  • BuildApps.Enabled = true
  • BuildApps.ApiType = rest
  • URL.headers.AI-Resource-Group = name of your resource group in the SAP AI Core – in my case it is “default”
    Note here that this is helpful if you use just one instance of the AI, located in one resource group. But if you use more AI instances and these instances are scattered among different groups, you can’t put the resource group name in the destination – instead you have to manage it in the application, in the REST API call.

 

And additional for the future use:

  • sap.applicationdevelopment.actions.enabled = true
  • sap.processautomation.enabled = true
  • MobileEnabled = true

 

 

Accessing AI from SAP Build Apps

Let’s go now to the SAP Build Apps.

  1. Open the “Integrations” tab
  2. Click “ADD INTEGRATION”
  3. Find the “SAP Systems” tile and click “BTP DESTINATIONS”
  4. Find and select the destination we just defined
  5. Click the “INSTALL INTEGRATION”
    That’s all we need to do on the integration level – we don’t need any entity here as we will just call the BTP destination and directly process the reply.

 

Adding AI-related components to the application UI

Open the “Record Details” page. Drag the following on the UI canvas:

  • A button, to send request to the AI – name it “Send request to AI”
  • A spinner, to show that the process is running
  • A text field with the AI’s interpretation

I would also suggest adding text fields to display cost of the interpretation denominated in the SAP AI Core tokens:

  • Input tokens
  • Output tokens
  • Total tokens

Now we need to define some page variables. Most of them we will populate with data we get from the AI:

  • PgVarInputTokens - number
  • PgVarOutputTokens - number
  • PgVarTotalTokens - number
  • PgVarAiInterpretation - text

But one page variable will be used to store the template of the request:

  • PgVarRequestTemplate – text – set the “Initial value” to:
    The following text is audit log record. Provide short interpretation in less than 50 words.

Note: We use the simplest possible approach in this demo app, suitable for very small, probably single person development team. But in the real life, production version it would make sense to use SAP AI Core prompt templating function. Especially when there is a dedicated AI team in your organization – in such case the application development team should use templates prepared in advance by the AI team for all the AI requests.

 

Another variable will be used to build request to the AI:

  • In correct form
  • Containing correct request

 

  • PgVarMessageToAI – this variable is an object, containing list of objects with two properties:

{

    "PgVarMessageToAI": {

        "messages": [

            {

                "role": "text",

                "content": "text"

            }

        ]

    }

}

 

 

 

Add also one variable to control visibility of the spinner:

  • PgVarSpinnerVisible – true/false – set the “Initial value” to false

Now we need to connect page variables with “Text” components: go to “User Interface” tab, open the “Record Details” page and assign each “Text” component its variable in the “Content” field.

The button logic

Now let’s build the logic to send request and to process the response. Select the “Send request to AI” button and open its logic canvas. Place and connect flow functions as shown on the following image:

 

 

 

Flow functions configuration:

  1. Set page variable PgVarSpinnerVisible to true
  2. Set page variable PgVarMessageToAI, field messages, to list of values:
    1. Role set to user
    2. Content set to formula and the formula to: pageVars. PgVarRequestTemplate +" "+appVars.MessageText
  3. HTTP destination request:
    1. Destination: select the destination pointing to your AI deployment
    2. HTTP method: set to POST
    3. Request body type set to json
    4. Request body set to PgVarMessageToAi
    5. OPTIONAL INPUTS Path: set to
      /chat/completions?api-version=2024-10-21
      if you use ChatGPT4o like me. If you use different LLM, you have to use different path, suitable for your type and version of the LLM.
  4. Sep page variable PgVarSpinnerVisible to false
  5. Set page variable PgVarAiInterpretation to
    outputs["HTTP destination request"].resBodyParsed.choices[0].message.content
    - this will glow in red and there will be a message that it is incorrect, but it will work anyway.
  6. Set page variable PgVarInputTokens to
    outputs["HTTP destination request"].resBodyParsed.usage.prompt_tokens
    – again, ignore the red color and error message
  7. Set page variable PgVarOutputTokens to
    outputs["HTTP destination request"].resBodyParsed.usage.completion_tokens
    – again ignore the message
  8. Set page variable PgVarTotalTokens to
    outputs["HTTP destination request"].resBodyParsed.usage.total_tokens
    – the same story as above
  9. Alert: select formula for Dialog title and put
    "Failure status code: "+outputs["HTTP destination request"].failureStatusCode+" | Failure status text: "+outputs["HTTP destination request"].failureStatusText
    in the formula
  10. Alert: select formula for Dialog title and put
    "Error code: "+outputs["HTTP destination request"].error.code+" | Error message: "+outputs["HTTP destination request"].error.message
    in the formula

Save the application and test it in the preview – you should see interpretation by AI after a few seconds from pressing the “Send request to AI” button.

Build, deploy and enjoy! The demo application is ready. Now you can modify it up to your liking – adding features, beautifying the UI.

Please let me know if you would like to get the above project as .tar file, ready to upload to your SAP Build Apps environment.

entry.title: Application Frontend Service now generally available in SAP BTP Trail Account [cf us10-XXX]
entry.content:
As part of our exciting  SAP Build release, we're happy to announce the release of Application Frontend service, a new SaaS application on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) Trail account for US region for hosting, serving and operating frontend applications.

SAP BTP Trial accounts can be deployed with limited to five(5) applications per subaccount.

Now, you can enjoy the following benefits of Application Frontend Service

What is Application Frontend Service?

Host, serve, and manage frontend applications to extend SAP business solutions.

Application Frontend service lets you host and serve frontend applications. It serves as a single entry point for hosting web-based UI applications to extend SAP's business solutions. The service provides tools for deploying and managing applications, serving static resources, routing backend calls to defined targets, and observability tools.

Application Frontend service is included in the SAP Build.

Application Frontend service supports various channels for managing applications, such as the commonly used Generic Application Content Deployer (GACD) for multitarget applications (MTA), a dedicated UI in the cockpit, and a CLI. These options allow you to choose the channel that best suits your needs.

Application Frontend is a SaaS application which is not coupled to any specific SAP BTP runtime environment or other SAP BTP applications. You can find and subscribe to the service from the SAP BTP cockpit. Application Frontend is also equipped with a service broker to support interaction flows using service instances, for example when using MTA deploy in the CF environment. 

While there is native support in the good old MTA concept for lifecycle management, Application Frontend also provides a command line interface (CLI) as a first-class tool for managing your applications. With the CLI, you can directly interact with the service and execute all actions supported by Application Frontend to enjoy fast response times and new integration opportunities.

High Level Overview of Application Frontend Service - Deployment

Prerequisites to enable Application Frontend Serivce

  • Go to your SAP BTP Trail Account - Subaccount
  • Go to your Instance and Subscription - Subscribe for SAP Cloud Identity Services
  • Enable SAP IAS and Trust & Auth with enabled SAP IAS
  • Go to Entitlements - Select Application Frontend Service
  • Select 2 checkbox for enabling the Plan (Developer and Application) 
  • Create a Role Collections and Assign to your User (SAP IAS enabled)

Go to Instances and Subscription - Select Application Frontend Service from dropdown with Plan - Trial

Go to Instances and Subscription - Select Application Frontend Service with Plan - Developer

Create a New Role Collection

Assign Role to newly created Role Collection

Application Frontend Service Library & CLI (Command Line)

npm install -g /appfront-cli

afctl login --sso -a <api_endpoint>

afctl push

 

Conclusion

Application Frontend Service is a game-changer for Cloud Foundry users. By simplifying UI development, enhancing scalability, and promoting consistency, AFS empowers developers to create high-quality applications more efficiently. As cloud-native development continues to evolve, integrating tools like AFS will be crucial in staying ahead of the curve and delivering exceptional user experiences.

For more detailed insights, you can check out the original blog posts : 

  • Introducing Application Frontend Service : Application Frontend Service 
  • Simple UI Applications with Application Frontend Service : DEV Community
  • Application Frontend Service Help Documentation : Guide and Development
  • Application Frontend Service Onboarding Service -  AppFront trial on-boarding help page

entry.title: Gamechanger Alert: Meet SAP Joule Studio for Real-World Impact
entry.content:
As someone who's still fairly new to SAP and learning about all it has to offer, I recently came across SAP Joule Studio—a tool that honestly surprised me. It’s part of SAP’s growing focus on AI, but instead of being just a tech buzzword, it’s something practical. Something helpful. Something that actually makes life easier.

So I thought I’d share what I’ve learned so far, for anyone else who’s curious like me.

 

What is SAP Joule Studio?

SAP Joule Studio is a low-code/no-code platform that lets you create AI-powered agents—little digital helpers that live inside your SAP system and support everyday tasks. These agents can:

  • Answer questions using real SAP data
  • Send reminders or alerts
  • Trigger workflows based on events
  • Help users navigate complex processes

The best part? You don’t need to be a developer to build one.

All you need is a good understanding of a business problem, and Joule Studio helps you turn that into a solution using easy visual tools.

 

Why This Is a Game-Changer (With Real Use Cases)

What really got me excited was seeing how real-world teams can use this tool to solve day-to-day challenges. Here are a few examples that really stood out to me:

✅HR & Employee Self-Service

  • Use Case: An AI agent that answers common HR questions like “How many vacation days do I have left?”, “What’s the process to update my bank details?”, or “When does my probation end?”
  • Impact: Reduces emails to HR, gives instant answers, and improves employee satisfaction.

✅Onboarding Assistant

  • Use Case: An AI agent that guides a new joiner through their first week—showing them how to complete paperwork, introducing them to teammates, and sending daily checklists.
  • Impact: Makes onboarding smoother, especially for remote hires or global teams.

✅Procurement Alerts

  • Use Case: A smart assistant that watches for delays from key suppliers and notifies procurement managers if a PO is stuck or overdue.
  • Impact: Keeps procurement responsive and improves relationships with vendors.

✅Project Management Summary

  • Use Case: A daily AI briefing that tells project leads about overdue tasks, timesheet gaps, or resource bottlenecks.
  • Impact: Saves hours of manual tracking and keeps teams aligned.

✅Compliance Checker

  • Use Case: A bot that checks which employees haven't completed their mandatory training or signed policy documents, and sends them a reminder.
  • Impact: Helps HR stay compliant without manual follow-ups.

✅IT Helpdesk Agent

  • Use Case: An agent that answers questions like “How do I reset my SAP password?” or “Where do I raise a ticket?”
  • Impact: Cuts down ticket volume for IT support and empowers users.

These aren’t just theoretical—they’re real issues we see in companies every day. And Joule Studio gives you a way to solve them quickly, without coding or waiting on IT.

 

Why Clients Will Love It Too

For clients, Joule Studio brings:

  • Self-service power to their SAP users
  • Less dependency on IT for small tasks
  • Smarter workflows with reminders, alerts, and guidance
  • Faster onboarding and training for new team members
  • Consistency across geographies and business units

AI becomes something helpful, not something scary or complex. It empowers users instead of overwhelming them.

 

Where You Can See It in Action

If you're like me and prefer learning visually, I highly recommend this official demo:

 SAP Joule Studio – AI for Everyone (YouTube)

You can also explore SAP’s official product page for more examples and how-to guides:
 SAP Joule Studio – Official Page

These are great starting points with visuals and real examples.

 

Getting Started with Joule Studio

If you’re ready to try it:

  1. Make sure your system is running on SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform).
  2. Go into SAP Build and access Joule Studio.
  3. Start by creating a small AI agent for a common task.
  4. Train it using real process examples and test in Preview mode.
  5. Roll it out with the right user permissions.

 

 

 

Remember—you don’t need to be technical. You just need to understand your business and what people are struggling with. Joule Studio helps you close that gap.

 

Final Thoughts (From One Learner to Another)

I’m still exploring SAP, still learning, and still asking questions. But tools like Joule Studio give me hope, not just for where tech is going, but for how we can make it work for people.

This isn’t about replacing humans—it’s about supporting them with small, smart helpers that remove friction and free up time.

If you're also exploring SAP tools and wondering where to start with AI, this might just be the right place. Try building a simple use case and see what it unlocks for your team.

And if you’ve tried it, I’d really love to hear what you’ve built. Let’s share and learn together, because the best ideas often come from the people closest to the problem.

 

#SAPJoule, #JouleStudio, #SAPBTP, #AIinSAP, #Gamechanger, #NoCodeAI, #SAPBuild, #EnterpriseAI, #DigitalTransformation, #SAPCommunity

entry.title: Automating Email with SAP Build Process Automation and Outlook Bot
entry.content:
In this blog, I will walk you through how I built an outlook automation bot that : -
i) Opens Microsoft Outlook.
ii) Sends a repetitive message with  .docx file attached.
iii) Closes outlook.
iv) Is released and deployed through the SAP Build lobby.

Creating a new automation project
First of all log into SAP Build Lobby.
Click create -> Automated Process->Automation and click on next


Name your project as ‘OutlookEmailAutomation’.
Provide a short description  as “ Bot to send daily emails with attachment via outlook”.

Click on ‘Review’ and then ‘Create’.

Designing the Automation Bot
In the automation section, click create -> automation and give the agent version


name it ‘sendemailbot’ and add description as ‘ bot for email automation’

Click on create.

Click on setting option, go to dependencies and  click on add -> Add a business process project dependency ( it is necessary to do this as then only we can get the different operations related to outlook in our tools section )

and then add ‘outlook sdk’


Add these steps by drag & drop from the tools section ;-

  1. i) Open outlook instance
    ii) Send email(Outlook)
    iii) Release outlook instance

In automation details section, go to input/output and set one input parameter for storing the document location which is going to be attached in the mail

In Send Email(Outlook) properties, fill all necessary details
( like In emailitemparameter add custom data,
set email fields
attach file path( here add the filepath variable for storing file location))


Test the bot locally
Click on test button and give the filepath ( i.e. the folder location)
e.g.


Ensure that there are no errors.


Release the automation
Navigate to project overview
Click release – set version 1.0.0
Add release notes : “ Initial release of outlook email bot”.

Finally Deploy the Bot
Go to deployments tab in the build lobby.
choose your bot and deploy version 1.0.0.
Assign it to a Desktop Agent that has outlook installed.
Trigger via manual execution or by scheduled trigger(e.g. every morning 9:00 am).

Benefits of this automation :-
It will save daily manual effort.
It reduces errors in repeated email content.
It ensures consistent report attachment.
It works even with outlook desktop app – no server-side integration required.

entry.title: Find the Bug 🐞 Formatting dates and times in Build Apps
entry.content:
Someone sent me a problem they were having in a private message, that made me chuckle.

To be honest, after 2 years of war and 2 weeks of intense war, and having to live out of a suitcase for a week in Athens because my plane was diverted and could not enter my country -- this was a fun, amusing diversion (it actually made me laugh).

Here's the message I received:

 

FORMAT_DATETIME_WITH_TIMEZONE(DATETIME("2025-04-03T02:00:00.000Z"), "MMM d, yyyy", "America/Chicago")

 

"I am using formula to format the date. Actually the output should be Apr 2, 2025, 9 pm. But I am getting Apr 3, 2025, 9 pm. How to solve this? I tried multiple ways. It's only changing time but not date. I used other timezone format as well. Please help. This is an issue in production."

After running the formula in my Build Apps and getting the same result, I assumed it was a bug in the tool (@Mari and @Pekka_Aaltonen, please forgive me). For the programmer, the obvious thing to think was that you asked for the date in the format April 2 (because it had to give the day before because the time zone they gave was minus 6 hours from UTC) and instead it was giving April 3. Why? Probably because the formula was too stupid to return the previous day's date.

It was supposed to show this:

But kept showing this:

But, alas, there was a perfectly logical explanation, but it was hidden because of the actual date and time used in the example. Another case of all-too-human error.

Can you find the bug in the function code?

P.S.: If you like this puzzle, wait for Devtoberfest in October. We'll have plenty more.

entry.title: Send OData Batch Requests in SAP Build Apps (JSON)
entry.content:
Many people have asked about sending OData batch requests via SAP Build Apps. It can be done, if your API accepts JSON-formatted payloads for batch requests.

Just use the HTTP Destination Request flow function.

Then set the following:

  • Destination: Create an integration with your destination that points to your API (no need to specify any entities).
  • Method: POST
  • Body Type: JSON
  • Request Body: Just define a page variable with the JSON schema you need, and set the values with a Set Page Variable flow function. More on this below.
  • Path: /$batch
  • Headers: Content-Type = application/json

Request Body

The request body would be something like this (here we are create new records):

{
    "requests": [
        {
            "id": "1",
            "method": "POST",
            "url": "/Orders",
            "headers": {
                "content-type": "application/json; odata.metadata=minimal; odata.streaming=true",
                "odata-version": "4.0"
            },
            "body": {
                "customer": "JSON1",
                "date": "2021-06-30T00:00:00Z",
                "status": "Initiated",
                "total": 99,
                "currency_code": "USD"
            }
        },
        {
            "id": "2",
            "method": "POST",
            "url": "/Orders",
            "headers": {
                "content-type": "application/json; odata.metadata=minimal; odata.streaming=true",
                "odata-version": "4.0"
            },
            "body": {
                "customer": "JSON2",
                "date": "2021-06-30T00:00:00Z",
                "status": "Initiated",
                "total": 100,
                "currency_code": "USD"
            }
        }
    ]
}

For my test, I already had the JSON above so I just put it in a JavaScript component, parsed it, and output it.

But you could create a page variable, and in your app populate the variable with your data. Then you could use this page variable for the request body.

Unfortunately, I could not find a way to use the more traditional multipart/mixed payload format from SAP Build Apps. If you can find a way, let us know.

entry.title: SAP Build Apps: Getting data with “Get Record Collection” or maybe “HTTP Destination Request”?
entry.content:
“Get Record Collection”

The most common (and comfortable) way to get data from backend is to use “Get Record Collection” flow function. All we need to do is to install an integration with SAP system via its REST API using SAP BTP Destination.

 

 

 

If we enable the “Autogenerate configuration” option during installation of the integration, we will get even definition of the data structure, ready to use as a template for data variables.

 

 

We can even easily add call parameters, which are to be added to the relative path as a query – all we need is to add additional inputs in the entity definition:

 

These additional inputs will be automatically added in the relative path and in the test section of the data entity. And we can use these additional inputs to send additional parameters with the API call:

 

 

And, as data variable uses in fact “Get Record Collection” flow function in the background, we also can do the same with “Get Record Collection” flow function:

 

 

When “Get Record Collection” is not enough

Sometimes we need some additional information, not only the data itself – we need access to the header of the backend response – something the “Get Record Collection” flow function can’t easily (if at all) provide. And this is the case with getting data from the SAP BTP Auditlog service I wrote about in the previous blog (SAP BTP Global Account audit logs using SAP BTP Auditlog service, SAP Build Apps and SAP Ai Core). The issue with the Auditlog service is hat it does not always send requested data in single run. If the response should contain more data, the Auditlog service will use “paging”. It will send first portion (page) only, and you will have to request next portion of the answer data, and next one, till all the data is received.

How do we know that our application should request next page of data? Auditlog service, when paging is used, adds appropriate information in the response header. If all the data is sent without paging, there is no additional information in the header. But if next page is ready for sending, the Auditlog service will add “paging” field in the response header. This “paging” field has the following structure:

Paging: “handle=<page id>”

The value of the “Paging” field looks like this:



As “Get Record Collection” flow function doesn’t give us access to the response header in any simple way, the better option to get data from the SAP BTP Auditlog service is to use the “HTTP Destination Request” flow function, which gives access to both: data and headers the easy way.

How to use this header field? The logic should go as follows:

  1. Empty the variable containing the data to be displayed
  2. Request data with the “HTTP Destination Request” flow function
  3. Add the body of the response to the variable containing the data to be displayed
  4. If the “paging” field exists in the response header: send next request for data to the Auditlog, but this time add value of the “paging” field to the request path as the last parameter and jump back to step 3
  5. If the “paging” field doesn’t exist in the response header: display the content of the variable containing data

The logic should look like this:

 

How to get access to the response header? Using a formula. We can use the “outputs["HTTP Request"].resHeaders” in the formula. As the header is a json, it is enough to know the names of fields in the header and then we can check if field exists in the header:

IS_UNDEFINED(outputs["HTTP Request"].resHeaders.paging

This function returns “true” if the field id undefined, otherwise it returns “false”.

And then, if we know that the field exists, we can get its value simply by its name like this:

outputs["HTTP Request"].resHeaders.paging

in the “Set App Variable” or “Set Page Variable” flow function.

I use both functions in single formula in the “Set Page Variable” flow function:

IF(IS_UNDEFINED(outputs["HTTP Request"].resHeaders.paging), "no_paging", outputs["HTTP Request"].resHeaders.paging)

If the “paging” field is not defined in the header, the formula sets “no_paging” as the variable value. But if the “paging” field is defined, the formula sets its value as the variable value.

entry.title: SAP Build Appsの「Repeat with」の使い方とポイント
entry.content:
SAP BTP Hackathon 2025が無事終了しました。ご参加いただいた皆様、ありがとうございました。毎年多くの方にご参加いただき、今年も大変盛り上がりました。
毎年参加チーム数や提出作品のレベルが上がっており、運営側としては嬉しい悲鳴でした。

 

その中で、今年はSAP Build Appsの「Repeat with」の使い方についてのご質問が多かったように思えましたので、使い方とポイントを解説したいと思います。

 

「Repeat with」機能とは？

「Repeat with」機能はUIデザイン上で同じコンポーネントを繰り返し使用するための機能です。例えば、リストやテーブルなど、同じ形式のデータを複数表示する場合に非常に便利です。
「同じコンポーネント」というのは、例えばテキストやImageなどのUI要素のことを指します。

これらのUI要素のRepreat withプロパティに「内部がオブジェクトになっているリスト型変数」をバインドすることにより、そのオブジェクトに残像のようなエフェクトが付きます。

「内部がオブジェクトになっているリスト型変数」とはSAP Build AppsのVariable上で以下のような定義の変数を指します。


変数定義としてはList型であり、その中のItemのタイプとしてObject型、そのオブジェクト型の中にTextや数値型などのプロパティを含んでいる構造です。これはJSONで記述すると以下のようなものになります。

[
  {
    "id": 1,
    "name": "Alice",
    "contact": {
      "email": "alice@example.com",
      "phone": "123-456-7890"
    }
  },
  {
    "id": 2,
    "name": "Bob",
    "contact": {
      "email": "bob@example.com",
      "phone": "098-765-4321"
    }
  }
]

実行時にRepeat withで繰り返し表示がされる回数は与えたリスト型の変数の要素数（長さ、Length）に依存します。例えば、5つの要素を持つリスト型の変数を指定すると、5回繰り返し表示されます。
 

使い方

上に挙げたJSONのデータを利用してみます。このJSONのデータ形式をSAP Build Apps上で表現すると下記のような変数になります。

JSONの値をこの変数に代入して、Repeat withで使用してみます。

Repeat withにSampleListをバインドします。このHeadLineアイテムのContent（表示内容）にnameのデータを表示したいと思います。HeadLineアイテムのContentのアイコンをクリックし


Data Items in repeatをクリックし、

Currentをクリックするとウインドウ下部に展開されます。

"current"は現在の行を意味し、その中のどれをContentにバインドするか？ということです。nameを選択します。
プレビュー実行してみます。

このように一つのHeadLineアイテムが勝手にリピートされ、バインドしたリスト型の変数の要素（行）を繰り返し、その現在行に応じたデータを表示してくれます。これがRepeat withの機能です。

更に実践

このRepeat withできる要素にはRowやContainer等複数のUI要素をまとめる機能を持ったコンポーネントも含まれます。
Rowコンポーネント中にはCellが含まれていて横に並ぶようになっています。このRowコンポーネントを縦に並べると表のようなものが出来上がりますね。Rowコンポーネントを4セル設定にして、各セルにTextコンポーネントを配置し、Rowコンポーネント自体にRepeat withで変数を設定して各セルにid,name,email,phoneのプロパティをバインドさせた例がこちらです。

Rowコンポーネントのスタイルを変更して枠線を追加すれば表になるなということがわかるかと思います。

ちなみに、ROWコンポーネントのCellに対してRepeat withで変数をバインドすると、


Listの要素数分横に並べるということも出来ます。

Listの要素数（行数）が多いので表示される行数を絞りたいという場合は変数操作が必要です。Repeat withでバインドする際にFormulaを使用して式の形でバインドすると良いでしょう。例えば

SELECT関数を使用するとリスト型変数から要素の範囲を絞ったものを抜き出すことが出来ます。

例1：　　SELECT(appVars.SampleList, index <10)
→ リストの先頭10件　（リストは0から開始します。）
例2：　　SELECT(appVars.SampleList, index >= 10 && index < 20)
→リストの11件目から20件目まで

応用すればページ表示のようなことも出来ますね。

画面の表示される範囲を制御したいという場合はRepeat withするコンポーネントをScroll Viewコンポーネントの中に配置すると良いでしょう。

そうするとScroll View側のスタイルの設定で、Scroll View内で表示されることになります。

Repeat withは必要な回数分UIコンポーネントを繰り返し表示できる便利な機能です。是非使いこなしてください。
